questions.stem: Complications of massive blood transfusion include:
Changes in electrocardiography of patients with pulmonary embolism include:
options: an S wave in lead V1
a q wave in lead III
new onset of left bundle branch block

questions.stem: Patients with pulmonary embolism involving the pulmonary artery have the following EXCEPT:
options: increased pulmonary resistance leading to right sided heart failure

questions.stem: In hypertensive emergency the initial aim is to decrease diastolic pressure by 10% in the first hour and additional 15% within 3-12 hours. The only two exceptions for rapid lowering of BP include:
A patient presenting with acute dyspnea to the emergency, his initial assessment revealed a high B-type natriuretic peptide (150 pg/ml). The following cause is suspected for his dyspnea:
The possibility of cervical spine injury should be considered in which of the following con-dition:
The following is an indication for oxygen therapy:
Regarding full thickness skin grafts which of the following is correct?
options: It has better survival rate than split thickness grafts.
It has better cosmetic result than split thickness grafts
It has high tendency of contracture.

questions.stem: Signs of lateralization include the following EXCEPT:
options: tilting of head to one side

questions.stem: Regarding ATLS for trauma, which of the following belong to the 2ry survey?
In maintaining normal subjects, pH of blood is maintained thanks to:
options: the kidney has no role in acid base regulation
reabsorption of ~ 80% of HCO3 in the proximal renal tubules
reabsorption of H+ in the proximal renal tubules
reabsorption of ~ 80% of HCO3 in the distal renal tubules

questions.stem: Septic shock :
options: is a type of hypovolemic shock
the patient is flushed and warm
is triggered by IgE – mediated release of histamine

questions.stem: The drug used as treatment of choice for FMF is:
A patient presented to the emergency with loss of consciousness, his initial physical examination revealed bilateral constricted pupils. The following is a possible cause for his condition:
options: uncal herniation with compression of 3rd cranial nerve

questions.stem: Patients with familial Mediterranean fever:
options: ECG may reveal diffuse ST-segment elevation
diagnosis relies on specific antibody titer
present with dull abdominal pain without rigidity
genetic testing showing mutation of MEFV gene is included in major Tel-Hashomer criteria for diagnosis

questions.stem: In patients presenting with hematemesis:
options: is only diagnostic with no therapeutic role
is done immediately after resuscitation and hemodynamic stabilization
upper endoscopy is the method of choice for diagnosis of perforated peptic ulcer

questions.stem: Non-cardiopulmonary causes for dyspnea include:
The mode of ventilation suitable for a patient in coma with respiratory center depression is:
Regarding the proliferation phase of wound healing, what is the correct statement is?
options: Platelet derived growth factor, tumour necrosis factor- alpha, interleukin-I.
Deposition of collagen in the wound.
Macrophages play an important role in phagocytosis and wound debridement.
Endothelial cells proliferate from the intact venules to form new capillary buds.

questions.stem: A 30-year- old patient taking blood transfusion. Few minutes later he started to complain of chest pain, dyspnea. On examination his pulse is 120/ minute, blood pressure: 80/60, the patient is oliguric with dark urine. The best treatment is:
A patient whose arterial blood gases reveal pH 7.25, PaCO2 50, HCO3 25 has:
An artificial airway, like an endotracheal tube, is used in the following type of ventilation.
Pressure is applied to the abdomen and thorax to draw air into the lungs through the upper airway in the following type of ventilation.
Iron lung ventilators used after the polio epidemics in the first half of the 20th century belong to...
One of the following modes of ventilation “locks out” the patient's efforts to breathe.
One of the following modes of ventilation has the risk of the patient getting respiratory alkalosis.
The mode of ventilation which allows the patient to breathe spontaneously at his or her own respiratory rate and depth between the ventilator breaths is...
Minute ventilation is equal to...
What are the Ventilator Parameters adjusted to maintain the optimum Minute Ventilation?
Which are the Ventilator Parameters adjusted to maintain the optimum oxygenation?
One of the following modes of ventilation reduces the work of breathing by overcoming the resistance created by ventilator tubing.
Which one of the following modes of ventilation is triggered by time, limited by pressure and affects aspiration only?
Which of the following ventilator modes delivers a preset volume or pressure regardless of the patient’s inspiratory efforts?
What is the recommended initial Fraction of Inspired Oxygen (FIO2) setting when starting mechanical ventilation?
Which of the following is a disadvantage of Synchronous Intermittent Mandatory Ventilation (SIMV)?
options: Increased work of breathing and respiratory muscle fatigue

questions.stem: What is the primary purpose of Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) in mechanical ventilation?
Which mode of ventilation is used for weaning patients and allows them to breathe spontaneously while reducing ventilator support?
